body: You can already do it via union queries. I don’t think it‘s worth adding it to druid itself.

@sixtus 
 I don't know how to do it via union queries. Could you please explain it？ Thanks.

> Pruning dimensions can reduce the number of rows. For example, there are two dimensions A and B in a segment. The cardinality of A is 10, and the cardinality of B is 100. The max number of rows in this segment is 10*100. However, if there is only dimension A in this segment, the max number of rows in is 10.

Could you explain what do you mean by "row" here? "Number of rows" in Druid terms could be "maximum" or "minimum", it's just static, and independent of dimensions's cardinalities.

I think what @zhangxinyu1 wants to point out here is that you will get better rollup when you have fewer dimensions with less cardinality, which means less rows to scan at query time which is expected to lead to better query performance. 

Havn't really thought through all the proposed implementation details, Few initial questions - 
1) How would segment versioning work between derived datasource and normal datasource ? 
2) What would be behavior for queries for which the interval is partially covered by the derived datasource and partially by the original one ? Will they be served fully by original or derived datasource? I expect it would be a very common case for realtime ingestion.  
3) are you considering doing that via an extension or a core feature ? I think an extension would be better option.

Let me use a more detail example to explain it.
Given a datasource with dimension A and B, such as:

Dimension A | Dimension B | Metrics A
-- | -- | --
a1 | b1 | 1
a2 | b1 | 3
a1 | b2 | 5
a2 | b2 | 7

In this datasource, there are 4 rows. 

If we prune Dimension B, we can get the datasource:

Dimension A | Metrics A
-- | --
a1 | 6
a2 | 10

There are only 2 rows in this datsource.

Then, we want to calculate `select sum(Metrics A) where DimensionA='a1'`. If we use the first datasource, druid need read the value of MetricsA in the first row and the 3rd row, and add them. But if we use the second datasource, druid only need read the value of MetricsA in the first row.

Ok, I understand now. It specializes for a specific aggregation, sum in your example.

I think your proposition with "transparent" data source names and special handling on historical query side is too complex. IMO it would be more reasonable to add handling of this on ingestion / batch indexing side, by adding some type of "multi data source ingestion spec", with multiple parts, where each part says the name of the output data source (not related to others, when segments are produced), dimensions to prune, and type of rollup aggregation (if any) which should be applied.

@nishantmonu51 
> I think what @zhangxinyu1 wants to point out here is that you will get better rollup when you have fewer dimensions with less cardinality, which means less rows to scan at query time which is expected to lead to better query performance.

Yes, that's exactly what I mean. Thanks.


> 1. How would segment versioning work between derived datasource and normal datasource ?

In the same interval, segment versions of derived datasrouces are always after normal datasources. In the same interval, if the segment version of derived datasource is before the related normal datasource, the derived datasource in that interval should be reindexed.

> 2. What would be behavior for queries for which the interval is partially covered by the derived datasource and partially by the original one ? Will they be served fully by original or derived datasource? I expect it would be a very common case for realtime ingestion.

It's a good question! I hope the query can be query can be served partially by derived datasource and partially by original. However, in this implementation, it's only served fully by original. Therefore, in this implementation, it cannot support realtime ingestion.

> 3. are you considering doing that via an extension or a core feature ? I think an extension would be better option.

Yes, I am considering do it via an extension. As far as I can see, some interfaces need to be added into core, is it ok?

There is no milestone on https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/5175 so this PR should go in the same version as the other PR.

What @zhangxinyu1 is proposing is a very old idea - the summary table. (Vertica called it a "projection" because they were academic relational folks, and so to them, projecting also implied removing duplicates.)

Summary tables tend to yield benefits if the number of rows decreases significantly, but their cost is additional storage and maintenance overhead. This would apply in Druid as in any other modern column-oriented database.

In my opinion, it is extremely important that summary tables are materialized views. That is, a user can write a query on the base data and the system transparently rewrites it to use the summary. This is important because it allows you to add/remove materialized views in future without breaking queries. We do this when we integrate Druid into Hive or Calcite; maybe Druid's native SQL (built using Calcite) could use Calcite's materialized views or lattices to achieve the same effect.

> @himanshug I don't think the druid.port at MM matters. The port finding logic in MM will find a available port before starting Peon. The druid.port won't be available at that time thus that port will be skipped.

I remember this being an issue at least once for a customer. When MM starts , it would select ports for the tasks to be restored and spawn peon process ( which would go on to start server sockets) asynchronously... and at this point MM would also starts its own jetty server ... a port conflict could happen in this situation if MM `druid.port` and startPort were same. I never confirmed it because problem was solved by just incrementing startPort by 1, but most likely above theory would hold.


> It occurs in a fairly low probability actually, but as our cluster becoming busier (more than 500 tasks at any moment), it's getting more serious, especially when working with tranquility, in which case tranquility will throw away a full segment of data.

if you have multiple replicants and at least one of them runs successfully then such data loss shouldn't happen. that said, starting Druid-0.12.0 , using KafkaIndexingService for realtime ingestion would be a better choice for many other reasons as well.

> I think it's not the problem of other services but a design flaw of Druid. In my opinion A better strategy may be Peon find a port and start the service itself and report to MM after that.

I see your point, it could be improved.

All said, We run many clusters with many many middle managers and don't hit this problem. what is your startPort ? Also, you can run following command to see what is your host's ephemeral ports range. Is your startPort very close to system ephemeral port range ?
```
$ sysctl net.ipv4.ip_local_port_range
net.ipv4.ip_local_port_range = 32768	60999
```
and, I'm assuming you have checked there aren't other services that would try and use same port range.

> you mean maxRowsInSegment -> maxRowsPerSegment ??!!

Yes
Cool, good to hear it's working!
@pjain1 #5175 is only in master, so we're good

> I don't think that increasing threshold param in the query would increase accuracy.

Increasing it should not have an effect on accuracy until you increase it beyond the minTopNThreshold. Then it will have an effect for the reasons that @pjain1 laid out.
@himanshug you are correct, added a note in the comment.

zhangxinyu1 thanks for the proposal.

here are my thoughts..

while tempting, it might not always be a good idea as you're duplicating data and need extra hardware to store/cache it. in some cases, it would be better to give that extra hardware to the original dataSources and queries might become faster without doing anything drastic.

it is already possible if customer desires so. Currently, it is done by many people by doing multiple ingestions to either create multiple dataSources from same input data .. or running batch `reindexing` on base dataSource. Clients don't directly talk to Druid, but to a Webservice on top of druid that handles query conversion.  ( I did https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/3482 to add some convenience on creation of those multiple dataSources, it fell off my priority list but something that could be added )
when user is doing it explicitly, they know exactly what is happening and the results they are getting.

if Druid does above automatically then it needs to be able to handle various scenarios related to updates made to base dataSource which is doable but would definitely add more complexity to querying logic.

Think about following scenario...
base dataSource A is indexed for interval Day1 , its segments have some version timestamp T. In the background, Druid submitted a job to create derived dataSource "A-Deriv" .. and around the same time user sent another indexing job for dataSource A for Day1... there is no guarantee that "version timestamp" generated for the segments for "A-Deriv" would be smaller than that of version timestamp of updated segments in A. Typically they are comparable for the same dataSource but not across because locking etc is per dataSource.
and, there might be other such corner cases to handle.

@leventov 

> I think your proposition with "transparent" data source names and special handling on historical query side is too complex.

Historical node doesn't do anything. Instead, broker replaces the base datasource with a derived-datasource, and coordinator is responsible for submitting Kill-Task or Reindex-Task when the timeline or version of derived-datasource doesn't meet the conditions.

> IMO it would be more reasonable to add handling of this on ingestion / batch indexing side, by adding some type of "multi data source ingestion spec", with multiple parts, where each part says the name of the output data source (not related to others, when segments are produced), dimensions to prune, and type of rollup aggregation (if any) which should be applied.

Thanks for your suggestion. It makes the design simpler, but how to add or remove derived datasources.

@jihoonson 

> I wonder what are the primary benefits of the derivedDataSource. Is the query speed the only one?

The primary benefits of the derivedDataSource is speed. Besides, it helps to use less CPU and memory.


> This can also happen even in batch append ingestion. I think this is important and should be supported because most Druid users will append new data to existing dataSources in some ways.

Yes, it's really important. I also considered it before, but I didn't come up with ways to implement it. Do you have some suggestions?

i found druid has fix it by set setMaxRows and  Iterator will traverse all items  , because ResultSetResultIterator will be closed when it call next to the end.  i guess the author didn't realize it.     
but i strongly suggest that ResultIterator call close manually
this only recurrence in mysql , ResultSetResultIterator.close will finally call mysql ResultSet.close  , so unit test (based on derby) will not recurrence

had a quick discussion with @akashdw offline. it appears that Druid is always writing the correct URIs as expected by S3 and HDFS naming conventions.
Problem is Distcp not supporting functionality to rename URIs as it writes to HDFS which doesn't support ':' . 

Its a one time activity and my suggestion is to do following.
1. copy relevant segments to another temp location on same S3 region.
2. rename segment files to replace ':' with '_'  as S3 can support '_' .
3. copy renamed file from temp location on S3 to HDFS.

then use insert-segment-to-db tool to update the metadata store correctly on the target Druid cluster.

@leventov thanks.

I would like to note the motivation around not merging druid-server druid-indexing-service. currently, Hive depends only on druid-server to power Hive-Druid integration . druid-indexing-service depends on indexing-hadoop and subsequently hadoop, so merge would require Hive to pull-in everything which might create conflicts and also bloat the hive packaging.

yes, that is a limit ... for now, you can't change the metric spec.

reason for that limit is related to "delta ingestion" support where user could be reading partially from Druid segments and partially late arriving data on hdfs. In that case, same set of aggregators must be used to read and process both datasets.
unfortunately, this restriction isn't really necessary for pure re-indexing use case but sneaking in from above use case.

https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/master/indexing-hadoop/src/main/java/io/druid/indexer/IndexGeneratorJob.java#L301 is the relvant code piece. we can probably add a hack config to forcefully not use combiningAggs even with SegmentInputRow and user could enable same for re-indexing only use cases. Unfortunately there is no clean-n-simple way to auto detect reindexing vs delta-ingestion.

Should I worry about this build failure? Seems bogus to me. Thousands of inspection errors all over the whole repo.

It looks like the inspections didn't report anything in the sketch extension, and of the three non-extension files changed in this PR, `SearchQueryRunner` and `DimensionSelectorUtils` weren't flagged.

For the changes in `AggregatorUtil`, it looks like the IDs that are referenced in only extensions get flagged as unused, so I think your patch isn't introducing any real inspection errors.

I think the merge with master is causing TeamCity to think that your PR has updated the files affected by the merge, so it's reporting pre-existing errors in those files.

maybe we can add come kind of flag somewhere (probably in `ingestionSpec`) so to state to ignore original specs?

I can see that this usecase could be pretty common in case you want to introduce new dataset (with higher granularity probably) and with some different metrics, but based on ones that are already in the datasource.

My usecase can be as example. We store realtime metrics, each having 5 dimensions. We poll them every 5 minutes and store values of that metrics in druid (with `queryGranularity` = 5 minutes), ending up with 25Gb of data per day. Then someone come in and say that "I want to be able to look at metrics for one month". Well the problem in that case is that druid have to look via 30days*25Gb=750Gb of data to get about 200 points to fit them into graph.

Then we realized that for that kind of tasks we better create a new data source with `queryGranularity` like 1 hour, but we better have some extra metrics along side, like minimum and maximum value during hour. So we decided to re-index all our existing data to create an new data source called `reindex-1h`, for example. Re-indexing task seems to be the solution.

But it seems that we cannot achieve that via re-indexing because each time our metrics, both new and existing one, are 0 in result :(

Yesterday I manage to get at least `count` metric to be non-zero, but `val` is always 0. I cannot use the same specs as in primary data source since in primary data source we have `val` metric defined as

```
{"type": "longSum", "name": "val", "fieldName": "value" }
```

because we have `value` field coming from kafka, and we store them as `val` in druid.

So I tried this as `metricsSpec` 

```
{ "name": "count",  "type": "count" },
{ "name": "val",    "type": "longSum",   "fieldName":"val" }
```

or 

```
{ "name": "count",  "type": "count" },
{ "name": "value",    "type": "longSum",   "fieldName":"val" }
```

and it gave `count` metric > 0 but `val` was still zeroes all the time.

So unfortunately it seems that we cannot re-index old data so that it could have couple more metrics :(

This PR will cause the native libraries for hyperic sigar that are packaged in the com.metamx java-util jar to be packaged in the druid java-util jar.

My understanding is, that in KafkaIndexingService, your metric spec was...
```
{ "name": "count",  "type": "count" },
{ "name": "val",    "type": "longSum",   "fieldName":"value" }
```
using same in reindex task is totally expected to work and I can confirm that we regularly use that in many of our own reindexing jobs. What version of Druid are you using?

Now, on the topic of being able to change metricSpec for reindexing jobs, I think it does make sense to have a config enabling that use case. Quick Patch in #5294 provides a boolean flag "readDruidRowsWithAggs" in "ioConfig" section to enable using arbitrary aggregators while reindexing. ( I'll probably need to change the flag name to something else more intuitive , but thatz for later).
Is it possible for you to apply the patch to Druid version you're using and run with that?

This PR addresses that querying on metastore may become slow if a lot of pendingSegments exist, but I think there are actually two different issues here. One is the growing pendingSegments table and another one is slow query speed on pendingSegments.

The first issue is fixed in #5149. So, I think this PR is still worthwhile if we can get a noticeable performance benefit. I'm not sure how slow the query speed is.
